subject: South Korea March 1st-20th Trade Balance at surlus of AUD 1.56bln, Exports rose 10.0% Y/Y and Imports rose 5.9% Y/Y
South Korea March 1st-20th Trade Balance at surlus of AUD 1.56bln, Exports rose 10.0% Y/Y and Imports rose 5.9% Y/Y
PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Japan is to extend curbs on entries from China and South Korea for about 1 month
content:
KDDI (9433 JT) - Co. is to launch unlimited 5G plan on March 26th. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. temporarily lays off 3000 workers at Spanish plants. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - WeWork board is said to be fighting against Co.’s cancelled plans to purchase shares in the Co. (Newswires)

Olympics - The International Olympic Committee has imposed a 4-week deadline to make a decision whether it will postpone the Tokyo Olympics. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan is to extend curbs on entries from China and South Korea for about 1 month, while it is expected to limit entry for travellers from US. (Newswires)

Previously reported stories: Canon (7751 JT) - Canon Medical to begin development of a rapid genetic test for coronavirus in partnership with Nagasaki University. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. is said to be seeking USD 10bln to shore up its Vision Fund amid crisis. In other news, S&P cut Co. outlook to negative from stable. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT) - IPO of Co.’s former chipmaking unit now named Kioxia Holdings is said to be facing clouds due to the global market turmoil which places risks on the more than JPY 1tln of unrealized gains Toshiba is set to make from the IPO in October.

Toyota Motor (7203 JT) - Co. is said to extend shutdowns at all North America plants through to April 3rd. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

LG Uplus (032640 KS) - Co. is to supply 5G VR content to Hong Kong’s largest telecoms firm HKT. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea announced tough social distancing measures for civil servants, public organization employees and soldiers nationwide. (Newswires)

subject: South Korea Vice Finance Minister says global economy is shrinking faster than expected, adds government will make all out efforts to avoid a credit crunch and will take market stabilizing measures if required

Australia Parliament is to meet today for special sitting to pass stimulus measures including additional AUD 66bln package which includes AUD 100k for small businesses and doubling unemployment allowance
Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) says Fed has infinite cash to support the financial system

Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) says US will at least have a mild recession, adds Fed will ensure banks have enough cash to meet demand and that Fed is being very aggressive but there is more we can do if needed
Queensland Premier says cabinet is to consider shutting state border and will make a decision on Monday
US Senator Democratic Leader Schumer believes coronavirus bill issues can be resolved in next 24 hours
US Senate Majority Leader McConnell says Senate will vote again at time of his choosing
analysis_details: • As a reminder, this follows the failure of the coronavirus bill fails to get enough votes to pass first procedural hurdle at the Senate, while Senate Democrats were said to be sending signals to Republicans on need to revise the bill as negotiations continue.

subject: US President Trump says congress are close to getting a deal completed on stimulus package to stem coronavirus impact on economy
RBA adds AUD 3.7bln to the banking system through repos
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: Australian PM Morrison said will close borders for up to 6-months or more
content:
AMP (AMP AT) - Co. in talks with interested parties about NZ wealth management business and will update before HY results in August. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. sees demand for jet fuel down by 80%-90%. (Newswires)

Finders Mines (FMS AT) - Co. CEO gives 3-month notice. (Newswires)

Flight Centre (GLT AT) - Co. will shut 33 stores in New Zealand. (Newswires)

Helloworld (HLO AT) - Co. announces stand down of around 65% of its group workforce. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT) - Co. is to temporarily suspend output in Malaysia. (Newswires)

Metals X (MKX AT) - Co. affirms current guidance but notes it is at risk from coronavirus. (Newswires)

NAB (NAB AT) - Co. Chief Customer Officer Healy is to resign; Co. notes coronavirus may adversely impact financial performance and position, while it is converting 7.5mln shares into notes. (Newswires)

oOh!media (OML AT) - Co. expected to announce AUD 167mln capital raise. (Newswires)

Reject Shop (TRS AT) - Co. notes last 4 weeks saw material rise in sales amid coronavirus concerns. (Newswires)

Santos (STO AT) - Co. postpones USD 7bln gas project and cuts spending. (AFR)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Moody’s cut rating from B2 to B3; on review for possible downgrade. (Newswires)

Tourism - Australia Tourism and Hotel Chief sent a letter to government requesting AUD 900mln relief package from the government and noted hotels were operating at below 10% occupancy rates. (Newswires)

Other News - Australian PM Morrison said will close borders for up to 6-months or more and restriction will not be lifted until it is safe, while he also noted that Australian states are mulling draconian measures to enforce social distancing. (Newswires)

US Senate coronavirus bill fails to get enough votes to pass first procedural hurdle, while Senate Democrats are sending signal to Republicans on need to revise bill while negotiations continue

subject: US Senate coronavirus bill fails to get enough votes to pass first procedural hurdle, while Senate Democrats are sending signal to Republicans on need to revise bill while negotiations continue
RBA excess cash at exchange settlement accounts rose to a record high of AUD 43.0bln on Friday vs. Prev. AUD 30.1bln
COVID-19 Case Count: 335,377 worldwide cases, 14,611 deaths, 97,594 recovered
content:
Figures provided as of Sunday (via here at time of posting) against previous of the prior day:

  • CHINA total cases 81,054 (prev. 81,008), death toll 3,261 (prev. 3,255).
  • ITALY total cases 59,138 (prev. 53,578), death toll 5,476 (prev. 4,825).
  • SPAIN total cases 28,603 (prev. 25,496), death toll 1,756 (prev. 1,381).
  • US total cases 32,356 (prev. 24,207), death toll 414 (prev. 302)
  • GERMANY total cases 23,129 (prev. 22,364), death toll 94 (prev. 84).
  • FRANCE total cases 16,018 (prev. 14,459), death toll 674 (prev. 562).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 8,897 (prev. 8,799), death toll 104 (prev. 102).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 7,474 (prev. 6,863), death toll 98 (prev. 80).
  • UK total cases 5,683 (prev. 5,018), death toll 281 (prev. 233).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 4,204 (prev. 3,631), death toll 179 (prev. 136).
  • CANADA total cases 1,426 (prev. 1,328), death toll 20 (prev. 19).

subject: US President Trump says we are fighting a war against an invisible enemy, but adds it is going to be a great victory
US President Trump says have approved New York and Washington requests for major disaster declarations, will approve California request soon
US equity futures hit limit down (-5%) within minutes after the reopen
US President Trump says US is marshalling every resource available to fight "Chinese virus", adds it is important Americans follow guidance on social distancing
US Senate Majority Leader McConnell says Senate to take first vote on relief bill now despite negotiations continuing
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump said he in not considering a national lock-down at this time and doesn't think it will ever be necessary. President Trump also said he is fine with restricting buybacks when asked about companies using fiscal aid to buyback stock, while he stated that he and Senate Minority leader Schumer are not far from reaching a deal on the stimulus package. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo announces that all non-essential workforce members in New York must stay at home and only essential businesses can have commuting workers, while the New Jersey Governor also signed an executive order directing all non-essential workers to stay at home. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the tax filing deadline will be moved from April 15th to July 15th, while he also believes rescue package will get done in Congress and will help half of US workforce. Furthermore, Mnuchin noted it will include a one-off USD 3k payment for families and the Fed is to leverage up to USD 4.0tln of liquidity, while he hoped to finalize legislation on Sunday for a vote on Monday.  (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said coronavirus stimulus packages could be around 10% of GDP and that small businesses will be receiving a payroll tax holiday under the bill. (Newswires)

US and Mexico agreed to restrict non-essential travel across their border as of midnight on Friday which does not apply to trade and commerce, while US-Canada restrictions to be reviewed after a 30-day period. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson announced the shutdown of cafes, pubs, gyms, theaters, cinemas and restaurants from Friday night, but noted that the government does not want to immobilize the tube or other travel networks. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak announced a combination of measures on jobs and incomes for the first time in which the government will help to pay wages. The measures allows any employer to be eligible for grants covering wages of those who have been furloughed and kept on salary in which the grant will cover 80% of salary of retained workers of up to GBP 2,500 per month, backdated to March 1st, for at least three months with no limit on funding available. Furthermore, COVID-19 loans scheme will be interest free for 12 months (prev. 6 months) and no business VAT will be paid until June-end, while Universal Credit increased by GBP 1,000 for the next 12 months and working tax credit also increased by GBP 1,000. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel tightens restriction amid the coronavirus in which no more than 2 people may be together in public places unless they are family or living together, while restaurants will be closed aside from takeouts and delivery for initially a 2-week period. In other news, German Chancellor Merkel reportedly quarantined herself at home after coming into contact with a doctor that tested positive for coronavirus. (Newswires)

German supplementary budget to counter the coronavirus will be significantly above EUR 100bln and could have a value of EUR 150bln, according to sources. There were also prior reports the German Government intend to set up a rescue package of EUR 500bln for companies and banks, while Germany is expected to authorize EUR 350bln in new debt to fight the coronavirus. (Newswires/Der Spiegel)

Spanish PM Sanchez is to seek parliamentary approval to extend state of emergency to April 11th. (Newswires)

India announced all districts in New Delhi is to be locked down and that the financial hub around Mumbai must be keep non-essential business closed until March 31st. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Chinese Premier Li said they will try every available measure to save smaller companies. (Newswires)

PBoC Vice Governor Chen said policy measures to address coronavirus have achieved significant results and expects China CPI increased to gradually ease, while Chen suggested China’s financial system remains stable and that they have ample policy tools. (Newswires)

IMF said China's Q1 slowdown will be significant but there are some signs of stabilisation/normalisation. (Newswires) 

 

FX

Banxico cut rates by 50bps to 6.50% in an emergency move, while it will add liquidity measures to provide liquidity and improve functioning of financial markets. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes US Rig Count (w/e 20th March): Oil rigs -19 at 664, Nat Gas rigs -1 at 106. (Newswires)

OPEC Sec General Barkindo spoke with the Texas regulator and were both said to be concerned of current market including the impact on the security of supply and discussed potential for future cooperation. (Newswires)

Some US energy officials were reportedly calling on Saudi to leave OPEC and are proposing a US-Saudi led partnership, according to sources. In related news, Texas officials are reaching out to the Trump administration regarding oil output cuts, while they are mulling a 10% cut if Saudi and Russia did the same. (Newswires/WSJ)

US officials said Russia will be sanctioned to the degree if it is caught lifting up Venezuelan oil. (Newswires)

Russia's Rosneft said oil could rise to USD 60/bbl by year-end if shale oil leaves the market, while it added that Russia and OPEC should maintain contacts. (RIA)

 

US

Fed, BoE, BoC, BoJ, SNB and ECB announced coordinated action for further liquidity provision via FX swap lines, daily from Monday (Prev. weekly), which will continue through till the end of April at the very least. (Newswires)

Fed expanded support for municipal and money markets via MMLF through the Boston Fed which is now able to lend to financial institutions secured by assets purchased from single state or other tax-exempt money market funds. (Newswires)

NY Fed is to make MBS purchases of at least USD 100bln in the upcoming week and will release a schedule each day for next day’s operations, while it is purchasing USD 40bln on Monday. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks reversed earlier gains into losses, marking a weekly loss of 15% for the SPX, albeit the VIX has cooled somewhat from its all-time highs mid-week. Investors continue to demand lower prices as the US and global economy begins to fall off a cliff amid a wide-ranging shutdown. Fiscal and monetary stimulus has been let loose and continues to ramp up – Senate is proposing a USD 1trln stage 3 package for Monday and UK is to begin paying wages for the first time ever – in a markedly more steadfast fashion than had been seen in the 2008/09 crisis, as policymakers strive to be proactive rather than reactive. US President Trump announced for any companies receiving aid he will demand there be no buybacks. The latest companies to request aid are the car rental services, Avis Budget Corp (CAR) & Hertz (HTZ). While the Airlines for Americas trade association said the industry needs “immediate financial assistance” to protect the 11mln jobs it represents. SPX -4.78% at 2294, NDX -4.04% at 6994, DJIA -4.55% at 19174.

The TPLEX bull flattened to end the week - 2s10s -10bps to 57.70; 2-year yield 0.356%, 10-year yield 0.94%, 30-year yield 1.58%. The bid was felt throughout the session, coming alongside equities rolling lower. Support was also found amid the Fed’s continued Treasury purchases, filling offers in poor liquidity as many participants are physically absent from their screens. Meanwhile, corporate IG issuance continued, following Thursday’s slew, with Intel and Coke raising USD 8bln and 5bln, respectively, while credit spreads narrowed slightly. Across the pond, the Euro issuance market even had a revival, no doubt the ECB’s latest PEPP package providing some confidence, seeing Engie and Unilever raise EUR 2.5bln and 2bln, respectively. T-note futures (M0) settled 1 point 16+ higher at 136-23+.

subject: Venezuela to suspend loans and interest payments for 6-month as a response to the coronavirus
RBNZ lends NZD 650mln via TAF facility, while it had offered NZD 2.0bln
US Senator Romney is going into self isolation as he was reported to have sat next to Senator Paul for extended periods recently, while Senator Paul has tested positive for coronavirus

content: • Via White House

subject: G20 finance ministers to hold teleconference at 1100 GMT on Monday, according to the French Finance Minister's agenda
RBNZ announces NZD 30bln large scale asset purchase programme of NZ government bonds over 12-months; to be purchased across a range of maturities in the secondary market
content: • Via RBNZ

subject: Senate procedural vote on Covid Bill has been pushed back to 1800 ET/2200 GMT, Senate Majority Leader McConnell says
IOC to discuss postponing Tokyo 2020 Olympic games; says cancellation is not on the agenda; decision could be made within the next four weeks
analysis_details:
• Tokyo 2020 organisers have begun considering plans to delay the summer’s Olympic games, it was earlier reported
  • Some scenarios are modelling a delay of up to two years, though organisers were hopeful for a month to 45-day delay.
  • Japan has already spent USD 12bln on preparations for the games, and reports suggest USD 3bln of sponsorship revenue may be at risk.
  • Other plans being considered involve holding the games without spectators, and/or scaling back the games.
  • Some organisers are pushing for a decision to be made quickly, warning that cancellation fees could rise the longer the decision is pushed-back.

subject: German Chancellor Merkel is in quarantine at home after contact with an infected doctor, spokesperson says
content: • Merkel will be tested over the next few days, and will continue to work from home
analysis_details: • Merkel has previously announced that she will not be seeking another term as Chancellor, and will step down before the October 2021 elections.

subject: Goldman Sachs says a temporary bounce could be coming; identifies six conditions markets need to rally
content:
Goldman Sachs said that given the amount of policy support announced each day - asset purchases, income replacement schemes and fiscal stimulus plans - a temporary bounce could happen at any time. For markets to recover, GS says they will need to be able to put limits on the current tail risks, and for new tail risks not to surface. GS identifies six conditions:

1) A stabilisation or flattening out of the infection rate curve in the US and Europe: GS notes that Chinese equities in February managed to rebound even without clear signs of an end to economic damage, so US stocks may respond to signs that containment measures are beginning to work. At this time, however, infection rates are still rising rapidly in large parts of the US and Europe, and there are some renewed infections in parts of Asia.

2) Visibility on the depth and duration of disruptions on the economy, which are currently unknown: GS emphasises that duration is critical: the difference between a 2-month and a 6-month period of disruptions is highly material. GS sees the peak disruption to activity occurring in April, though notes uncertainties.

3) Sufficiently large global stimulus: Market troughs are characterised by both a stabilisation in data but also a strong policy response that finally gets ahead of the deterioration in the data, GS says, and the current policy response is also beginning to become more urgent and more broad-based. But the bank believes central banks have scope to boost support, while fiscal responses are assuming a relatively short period of disruptions to the economy; GS says that authorities have made moves in the right direction, but more may yet be needed.

4) A mitigation of funding and liquidity stresses: Funding stresses and liquidity problems have also taken centre stage, adding to the economic risks, and GS believes central banks will need to  expand their role as "purchaser of last resort" to avoid many fixed income markets remaining dislocated.

5) Deep undervaluation across major assets and position reduction: if valuations come close/overshoot worst case scenarios, risk-reward may be appealing even with high uncertainty, GS says. GS sees significant cheapening across assets over the past couple of weeks and says pockets of deep value may now be emerging, though we are not at overshooting levels yet. It notes that in EMFX, the median currency is now through ‘moderate’ levels of undervaluation, but estimates further depreciation to reach GFC-type 'severe' undervaluation. EUR sovereign spreads are not yet in overshooting territory, and neither are equities. The bank says valuations are rarely a sufficient condition for markets to recover, but an unusually large risk premium would allow investors greater comfort in terms of stepping back in if other conditions are fulfilled.

6) No intensification of other tail risks: GS says that the longer this crisis lasts, the higher the probability that other tails risks intensify further. Risks that it is watching include: a further dollar spike; even lower oil prices; politics and its spillovers into sovereign spreads and funding (migration crisis in Europe, Brexit, worsening in US-China relations).

GS does not think these conditions have yet been met, and continues to suggest a defensive posture; however, it does note that it is also easier to imagine how those conditions might be met in the weeks ahead than it was even a week or two ago.

subject: UPDATE: Senate may hold procedural vote on USD 2trln covid aid package later on Sunday
content:
• Congress is near a USD 2trln aid deal to provide support to the economy amid the covid fallout.
  • The package would include aid to small businesses to retain staff; direct cash payments to Americans, and enhanced unemployment insurance; USD 110bln aid to hospitals and medical workers.
  • There will be support for airlines, assumed to be around USD 50-60bln of loans; airlines have also called for USD 29bln "worker protection grants"; airlines employ around 750k staff. Airline CEOs on Friday warned Congress "time was running out", amid revenue warnings. Airlines may face share buyback bans under any aid deal.
  • The Bill will also give the Fed authorisation to launch emergency lending, which could provide USD 4trln of liquidity
  • Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the measures would help businesses "get through" the next 90-120 days.
  • Mnuchin hopes Congress will Monday vote on the package. A procedural vote could take place Sunday, ahead of passage on Monday; however, this would depend on whether lawmakers can strike a deal on the Bill; House Speaker Pelosi, when asked if there will be a deal, said that from her standpoint, the sides were still apart.
  • The Bill could have a price tag of USD 1.4trln, along with an additional USD 400bln of potential Fed liquidity.

subject: US President Trump says Ford (F), General Motors (GM) and Tesla (TSLA) are being given the go ahead to make ventilators and other equipment
content:
• Via Twitter
  • Trump also thanks FedEx (FDX) for making rapid emergency deliveries
analysis_details: • Some other nations are expected to make similar moves; Germany earlier had reportedly asked automakers to produce medical equipment too.

subject: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says situation in the US looks like a 10-12 week scenario; hopes Congress will vote on package on Monday; says administration can stabilise the economy, and will go back to Congress for more support later if needed
content:
• Virus support measures will aim for US businesses to get through the next 90-120 days.
  • Measures for families would be one-time, for now.
  • Says bill will include USD 4trln of liquidity for the Fed to support the economy.
  • Asked if the US was in a recession, Mnuchin said it is a technical question, not reelvant now, adding he expects to see an economic 'hit' next quarter.

subject: COVID-19 Case Count: 315,796 worldwide cases, 13,593 deaths, 95,892 recovered
content:

subject: WHO's Ryan told BBC on Sunday a covid vaccine could take at least a year to develop; Ryan also warned that when lockdowns are lifted, cases could begin to rise again
Australia PM Morrison overnight said that the announced fiscal measures will not be the last; Treasurer Frydenberg said the government will partner with banks to boost lending to SMEs.
content: • Morrison also said extreme measures ae being considered to enforce social distancing; venues like pubs and restaurants will close from Monday to combat the virus, although schools would remain open.

subject: PBOC Deputy Governor Chen overnight said downward pressure on the global economy is increasing due to covid; expects upward near-term pressure on CPI to persist
content:
• Says with the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak being kept under control and market supplies improving, consumer inflation in China is likely to ease in the following quarters,
  • Price stability is largely subject to the economic fundamentals, and China's overall balance of supply and demand and stable macro-economy does not support long-term inflation or deflation. 
  • PBOC will pay attention to the flexibility and appropriateness when implementing the prudent monetary policy to strike a balance between ensuring growth stability, preventing risks and containing inflation.
  • China financial system remains stable, no big rise in defaults, and PBOC has ample tools.
  • Chen sees the economy undergoing a significant improvement in Q2.
  • Enacted measures are having significant success, and China's economy is improving due to the measures.
  • Says countries should strengthen policy coordination.
  • PBOC is in contact with other central banks; Governor Gang exchanged views with the Fed chair, Chen said.
  • PBOC will continue rate reforms.
  • Chen sees CNY remaining around 7.00 against the USD in the near-term, and expects the yuan to remain stable.
  • Too early to say if there is a global recession.

subject: UK regulator FCA late Saturday called on UK listed companies to observe a two-week moratorium on the publication of preliminary financial statements
EU commissioner Gentiloni said the bloc aims to strike a deal within days on new fiscal measures to support the economy, according to the FT.
content:
• Three options are being considered: 1) ESM offering more credit to member states; 2) narrower liquidity facility to finance health care spending; 3) 'coronabonds' issued via a European institution like the ESM to finance the response.
  • The piece also suggests that officials are trying to break the stigma attached to tapping ESM funding.
  • The article suggests that officials are hoping to settle on a rescue package at a call of Eurogroup finance ministers on Tuesday evening.
  • Via FT
analysis_details: • Chimes with an interview given by EC VP Dombrovskis on Saturday.

subject: Kuwait oil ministry on Sunday said all steps were being taken to ensure production continues, despite coronavirus outbreak.
content: • Also announced an extension of business suspension; ministry will resume work operations on 12th April.
analysis_details: NOTE: Kuwait was producing 2.66mln BPD at the end of February

subject: Libya NOC late Saturday said it will be reducing staffing at oil fields and ports due to coronavirus; emergency teams will be kept in place.
Tokyo 2020 organisers consider plans for games delay
content:
• Tokyo 2020 organisers have begun considering plans to delay the summer’s Olympic games, sources said
  • Some scenarios are modelling a delay of up to two years, though organisers were hopeful for a month to 45-day delay. 
  • Japan has already spent USD 12bln on preparations for the games, and reports suggest USD 3bln of sponsorship revenue may be at risk. 
  • Other plans being considered involve holding the games without spectators, and/or scaling back the games. 
  • Some organisers are pushing for a decision to be made quickly, warning that cancellation fees could rise the longer the decision is pushed-back.

subject: Germany could issue EUR 350bln of new debt to finance support for the economy amid the covid fallout, sources said (Saturday); would include a EUR 150bln supplementary budget
content:
• The German government could issue EUR 350bln of new debt to finance support for the economy amid the covid fallout, sources said (Saturday), and the EUR 350bln would include a supplementary budget of around EUR 150bln. 
  • There would be EUR 100bln made available for an economic stability fund, which would be able to take direct equity stakes within companies; EUR 100bln in credit to development bank KFW to provide loans to businesses. 
  • The sources said the details of the package were yet to be fully agreed. 
  • Finance minister Scholz confirmed a EUR 150bln budget would be presented. Separately, Germany has reportedly asked automakers to produce medical equipment for the coronavirus fight (Sunday).

subject: European Commission to present plans on Monday to mobilise the ESM to aid the virus response, VP Dombrovskis said on Saturday
content:
• European Commission VP Dombrovskis said (Saturday) the EC will on Monday propose to European finance ministers an instrument to mobilse the ESM bailout fund’s EUR 410bln of unused lending power to help with the coronavirus response. 
  • The measures may unlock unlimited ECB government bond buying, Reuters reported. 
  • One issue is the size of the fund, which was created to respond to asymmetric economic shocks, whereas covid is a symmetric shock which impacts all member states, Dombrovskis said; he emphasised the importance of a dedicated ESM tool which could unlock the ECB’s OMT programme to potentially buy an unlimited about of government bonds at primary auctions, since there is a fear that the ESM’s resources – which currently involve credit lines to governments – might still not be enough. 
  • To provide these credit lines, the ESM would need to borrow cheaply via “coronabonds” issuance. 
  • The EC VP also said the Commission will propose a European unemployment re-insurance scheme based on loans, since any economic fallout from covid would likely see a sharp rise in joblessness, though this would be presented in Q4.

subject: Fed’s Bullard (non-voter, dove) Sunday reiterated that the Fed was willing to do more to help address the coronavirus crisis
content:
• Fed’s Bullard (non-voter, dove) Sunday reiterated that the Fed was willing to do more to help address the coronavirus crisis. 
  • Bullard argued that a fall in output, and a rise in unemployment should be marched ‘dollar for dollar’ with government borrowing, and the full offset of wages would set up for a rapid rebound; a sharp contraction in Q2 could be seen as an investment in public health. 
  • Bullard expects the slowdown to be temporary, and added that a sharp rise in unemployment to as high as 30% should be a sign people are staying at home.
